block.p: Mideast Summit Begins As Violence Continues Israeli and Palestinian leaders met in Egypt with President Clinton, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, King Abdullah of Jordan, Secretary General Kofi Annan and a senior envoy from the European Union to try to negotiate a truce.
Stone-throwing clashes punctuated by gunfire erupted across the West Bank and Gaza Strip as thousands of Palestinians took to the streets.
Hezbollah's leader said an Israeli taken captive by the group was a spy who had been lured to Beirut in a cloak-and-dagger operation. Israeli officials say he is a businessman.

Reversal on Terror Attack Yemen's government, which had denied that the deadly blast that damaged the destroyer Cole was a terrorist attack, denounced the attack as ''a premeditated criminal act'' and said 1,500 people had been questioned in a police sweep.

Milosevic Allies Back Down Slobodan Milosevic's party ceded its last bastion of power, agreeing to share power in a transitional government of Serbia ahead of new parliamentary elections, which will now take place on Dec. 23.

Philippine Leader Talks Tough President Joseph E. Estrada, embroiled in a widening scandal involving reported kickbacks from gambling rackets, sounded a defiant note in remarks to journalists. A coalition of business groups is expected to call for his removal from office, through resignation or impeachment.

S. African Retreats on AIDS President Thabo Mbeki, who confounded much of the world by challenging prevailing scientific thinking on AIDS, will curb his comments on the cause of the disease, the government's chief spokesman said.

Former U.S. Envoy Testifies A former United States ambassador to El Salvador, Robert E. White, testified in a suit brought against two retired Salvadoran military officials living in Florida. Mr. White said he believed the men helped cover up the murders of four American churchwomen in El Salvador in 1980.

Campaigns Intensifying Pace of TV Ad Spending The Gore and Bush campaigns, their parties and outside groups spent a total of $18.5 million on television ads in just the last week of September and the first week of October. The bulk of that money, $14.5 million, was spent in six highly contested states: Florida, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.

Debate Moderator Under Fire Jim Lehrer of PBS, the moderator of all three presidential debates, has drawn criticism from partisans and analysts who say he has not pressed the candidates and was not aggressive enough in following up his questions. He rejected the criticism.

Vice President Al Gore gathered nearly two dozen people near St. Louis to help prepare for his third and final campaign debate tonight with Gov. George W. Bush. Their message was, be yourself. The debate will be in a town-meeting format, with questions from the audience.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said that his and Mr. Gore's policies stemmed from fundamental American and religious principles. He cited such disparate sources as the Ten Commandments and the Declaration of Independence and precedents as varied as the civil rights movement and the creation of Medicare.
Mr. Bush, campaigning in Arkansas, derided Mr. Gore as an old-time Democrat who favors big government, a theme he promised to strike in tonight's debate.

Dick Cheney continued to press his case for maintaining a strong military even in peace, invoking not only the attack on the destroyer Cole but also the hostage crisis in Iran and President Jimmy Carter's ill-fated effort to rescue the captives.
Family Gathering on the Mall Tens of thousands heeded Minister Louis Farrakhan's call and gathered in Washington in a daylong commitment to renewing family solidarity as a force in American life.
Gus Hall The lifelong Communist who led the American branch of the party from the cold war through political oblivion in the post-Soviet era was 90.

Reports of Corruption Prompt Dominican Inquiry The newly elected government of the Dominican Republic is investigating complaints that the Dominican consulate in Manhattan has been charging excessive fees and that Bienvenido Perez, the consul general from 1996 to 1999, manipulated prices to benefit himself.

Belt-Tightening in Nassau The Democrats who control the Nassau County Legislature said that to prevent a state takeover of county finances they would seek a double-digit percentage rise in property taxes and reject costly police raises.
Twins, 13, Accused of Rape Two boys, identical twins, were arrested in the rape and robbery of a 40-year-old Bronx woman.

Bilingual Programs at Risk A draft report by a mayoral task force recommends that New York City public school students who do not speak English be given the option of taking all subject classes in English, a proposal that would probably curtail many bilingual programs.

Rising College Tuition Costs The costs of attending private four-year colleges grew by 5.2 percent this year, to $21,339 a year, while costs at public four-year colleges rose by 4.4 percent, to $8,086.

Behind the Desire to Eat A new wave of scientists is getting at the molecular causes of appetite and satiety, unraveling elaborate chemical pathways that control how much animals, including people, eat.

Little Guidance on Altered Corn Some farmers who planted StarLink, which is not approved for human consumption, say they were not adequately warned about restrictions on its planting, storage and sale. Industry officials say millions of bushels of the bioengineered corn may have entered production channels.
$36 Billion Oil Merger Texaco and Chevron announced Chevron's acquisition of Texaco, which has been weakened by missteps and waning market interest.

Airline's Profits Surge Continental said third-quarter profits rose 32 percent, beating Wall Street expectations. But some analysts warned that industry profits over all would weaken because of higher oil prices.
Mets Clinch N.L. Pennant The Mets beat St. Louis, 7-0, in Game 5 of the league championship series, raising prospects for a Subway Series against the Yankees, who face Seattle tonight.
Ailment Sidelines Mourning The Miami Heat center Alonzo Mourning, 30, said he would sit out the N.B.A. season because of a recently detected kidney condition.
Editorials: The terrorist threat at sea; confusion over child health coverage; Michael M. Weinstein on affirmative action. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Gail Collins.
